string.text: Is there something in that room?

Not something, someone. That guy in there is a veteran - he can get anyone any kind of equipment, even unique stuff. He isn't accepting any visitors, though - gotta make sure you're trusted for that. Gonna need a name around here.
So, can I meet this man now?
Hm... Alright. I'll let Garry know. The name of the guy is Nimble. Head straight and then right along the corridor.
Is there something in that room?

Not something, someone. That guy in there is a veteran - he can get anyone any kind of equipment, even unique stuff. If you want to see him, go ahead - I trust you. Tell Garry I said you can pass - head straight and then right down the corridor. His name is Nimble.
I need to pass through.
Are you the stalker who broke through the Brain Scorcher and lived there for half a year?
Well, not half a year, just over a month. But yeah, name's Miklukha. Nice to meet you.
How was it?
Sorry, but I'd rather not start reminiscing. What matters most is that I got out safe and sound.
Got it. Thanks anyway.
Hello, Gatekeeper.

Hey there. Going to Limansk, are you? If it weren't for Leshiy... Anyway, welcome. Gonna need the money from you... And be careful not to get caught by our patrols - they aren't part of the agreement.
Here's the money.

Very well. I'll give the heads-up to the watch at the bridge. Once you get there, the one to speak to is "Gatekeeper". Just act cool, and please try to find something that would shed some light on the disappearance of Scar.
I'm looking for Leshiy, is he with you?
He sure is. Head down to the first floor, he's at the end of it.
Thank you.
Leshiy, right?
Yep. Need a guide, or did you want anything else?
Well, I know something about your past. I could use your help, merc.
Uh... What kind of help?

Could you talk to the mercs guarding the bridge in the Red Forest? I need to get to Limansk. I understand that this might be inconvenient, but I can promise you that I'll try to find any tracks left by the mercenary Scar.

Hm. You gotta understand that I haven't been part of the Syndicate for a long time... Not even sure who runs the group at the bridge. I've got a few connections, but I'm gonna need some time for this... and some money. One hundred and fifty thousand, no less.
Forester, I need to get across the Limansk bridge.
Across the bridge, you say? Why don't you go speak with the ones guarding the bridge?
You may have forgotten, but it is thanks to you that Limansk is now swarming with mercenaries.
I haven't forgotten, but you will not get any help from me, either. I'm still not sure if I did the right thing by helping those mercenaries.
Listen, you need to help me. What does it matter if you did the right thing or not? In any case, I can find out if I'll be able to reach the city.
If you don't tell me about everything this instant, you're going to get a free ticket to the morgue.
Old man, if the Zone wants me at Limansk, I'm gonna get there. It's in your best interest to help me, because no one knows if it'll be supportive to you next time.

...I saw something in Scar - the Zone needed him. You, however... Yes, I'd like to know what happened to him. So, listen: we helped the mercenary detachment get out of the space anomaly. Once everything was settled, they paid me a visit. Looks like one of them snitched on me, told them I also took part in the rescue. I spoke to their leader, Leshiy, who gave me some provisions, money and ammunition - then he went on his way. In his own words, he headed off to the Army Warehouses - to Freedom. You can go look for him there - several years have passed, but judging by our conversation, his intentions to join them were serious.
I've heard something about the history of your group. I would like to investigate.

You looking for something, or what? Hah, listen. You have virtually no chance of surviving in those areas - but even if you do, finding information about our stay there ain't exactly gonna be a walk in the park.
Aren't you interested? Or is there something you want in return?
Hmm... You can help us take out a pack of bloodsuckers in the swamp, and maybe then I'll share what I've got with you.
Fine, give me the coordinates.
There you go - have fun.
It's done. What info do you have?

So I've heard - well done. You're a good fighter and I trust you, so I'll give you what you need. The boys have probably told you about the assault at that damned bridge in Limansk. In case you don't know... Back then, in the city - as well as the surrounding area in the Red Forest - mercenaries were in charge of everything. Of course, they aren't going to just lower the bridge for you, but there is a live participant in those events - they call him Forester. It was him, along with Scar, who somehow agreed that a group of "standards" would lower the bridge while our fighters protected them from the other shore. Here, I'll give you info on a route between the Army Warehouses and the Red Forest - use it to find Forester and talk to him. And here's a reward for the bloodsucker cleanup.
Thank you.
Need a check-up.
Ah, of course, can't even keep yourself in one piece. Let's see...
Hands and feet are okay... Dick is in place... Yeah, you're alright.
How bad is it?
Fuck, man, I don't understand any of this shit. Whatever, you should be better now.
I need medical assistance.
Okay, let's see...
Everything's fine.
How bad is it?
Right, everything should be in order now... I hope.
I need medical assistance.
Huh? Right, come on over.
Dude, you're healthier than a bloodsucker.
How bad is it?
This might sting a bit. Right, you stay healthy now.
How do I get out of here?
This place is surrounded by all sorts of danger, but we've got an underground sewer network. There's a guide who can get you out of the city to one of our few bases, located in southern Zaton.
Remind me, where do the routes lead?
Your only option is the waste processing plant in southeastern Zaton. It'll cost you eight thousand rubles.
I want to leave the city.
You sure? Our only option is to the north - we'll be arriving at the waste processing station in southern Zaton. Eight thousand rubles.
I'm ready, let's head to Zaton. %c[255,238,153,26][8000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Who are you?

I could ask you a reasonable question in return: what's your damn business? But that's probably not what you wanna hear, is it? I work as a trader, as well as a guide - and I know a route to our main outpost in Zaton.
Could you remind me where the routes lead?
There's only one route, remember? It leads to the Dead City, and it's eight grand.
I want to get to the Dead City.
Then we've got a ways ahead of us. Get the cash out and let's get moving.
I've changed my mind.
I spoke to Noah.
Oh, I forgot about the request. So, what does he have there?
They say her name's Lassie. She's got two puppies, and they haven't shown any kind of aggressive behavior.

Puppies? Never thought you'd ever see that in the Zone. Well, thanks - now I know that there are more friendly pseudodogs breeding in the Zone. Here are some provisions for your future journeys... And, if you need it, you can have some information about a route between the Army Warehouses and the Red Forest. It's remained with us like an echo from the past.
Who are you?
I'm a local informant, and I can offer you all kinds of services. At the moment, I have different types of information and maps with routes to various locations. Don't ask where I got this stuff.
Got any fresh information?
I've got information about the swamp doctor, for seven thousand.
I'm listening.

The old man is in the Great Swamp, always waiting for his friend Strelok. Someone came up to him recently, and the Doctor told him his story and everything else important - the story of Strelok's group itself! You can go to him and see it for yourself.
Got information about some stalker looking for Strelok's group, for ten grand.
I'm all ears.

This very stalker who went to Doctor is now looking for traces of Strelok's group. He's already been to the laboratories in Dark Valley and Yantar, and it's obvious he ain't stopping there. Judging by proven sources, he wants to break into the center of the Zone and finish what the group of stalkers never managed to carry through.
I have information that sheds light on the second shutdown of the Brain Scorcher, but only for fifteen grand.
Gimme.

This same stalker turned off the Brain Scorcher! I wonder when they're gonna try tearing up the control center instead of turning off the switch every time? There are rumors that he's currently heading to Pripyat and that he had some assignment from the Doctor. I don't know if the old man wants to find his friend, or if there's something else behind it.
I can post information about the adventures of a mysterious stalker who explored the Generators for twenty-four thousand.
Pass it.

Have you ever heard about the Generators? Until recently, they were only considered a myth... but after Strelok's second campaign to the center of the Zone, there's no doubt they're real. There have been constant disputes about what they are, but old satellite imagery suggests some kind of weird infrastructure, in whose honor the entire area was named. Apparently, that's the place where Monolith carry out their orders and all important processes on the territory of the Zone. So, the stalker's already gone there and I think he's serious - his intervention might have a major impact on the Zone. The leaders of a few groups have already expressed their discontent regarding this information.
Not at the moment.
Not interested.
I'd like to buy intel on a few routes.
Certainly. Here's what I've got.
From the Army Warehouses to the Radar. %c[255,238,153,26][25000 RU]
So, do you have the money for it?
Yes, here you are.
From the Radar to the bunker below it. %c[255,238,153,26][37500 RU]
Got the dough?
Of course. Here.
From the Radar to Pripyat. %c[255,238,153,26][50000 RU]
Have you got the cash?
Here you go.
From central Pripyat to the Outskirts. %c[255,238,153,26][100000 RU]
I'll need the paper, first.
Yeah, here it is.
From Pripyat to the Chernobyl NPP. %c[255,238,153,26][150000 RU]
Have you got any money with you?
Yes, there you go.
Between the southern and northern parts of the Chernobyl NPP. %c[255,238,153,26][175000 RU]
Money first.
Here you are.
I don't have the money.
I've changed my mind.
Need any help?
Well... I do have a couple favors you could do for me.
Find a new shotgun

My current shooter is crap. If you could bring me something better, like a Saiga... Well, I'm not sure getting a weapon like that in the Zone is possible. I have seen a few bandits with Armsel Protectas, though. You can bring me one of those.
Deal with the snorks at the southern plateau

It's time to put an end to those horrid creatures. Every night, I hear them creeping around the barge, waiting, breathing and sniffing. To get to the southern plateau, you'll have to use a teleporter. I've marked it on your map - it's not far from the burnt farmstead.
I've changed my mind.
Here's an Armsel Protecta.
...Impressive. Thanks for the help. Now those beasts will think three times before snooping around here.
I got those snorks, there were quite a few of them. What were they hunting you for?
I'm not sure. I used to head over there once in a while to clean them up, but I don't have any more time for that... have to to keep an eye on the puppies. So, thank you for your help.
Man, what the hell were you shooting for? You almost killed me!
And what are you here for? No bullshitting - don't waste my time.
Okay, easy. Just passing by. Need any help? Can you answer a few questions?
I'll answer, but don't screw around.
I have a couple of questions.
Where did you get this dog?

That's Lassie. A sweet little bitch... If not for her, I'd have been devoured in my sleep long ago. Cursed mutants... I hate them! Soon as you close your eyes, they start reaching for you with their nasty claws, fangs and feelers...
I see.
And those puppies - where do they come from if she's next to you all the time? Heh.
Why do you live on this garbage can?
It's an ark! Remember that... you will, if you want to live! When a Wave starts, stay close. Here you'll have a chance to survive. No mutant will ever break in here.
What "Wave"? What are you talking about?

The creatures are watching me day and night. You do not understand... those snorks from the southern plateau have followed me right up to the Ark! I'm an experienced hunter and I know that they would not have chased the victim for so fucking long. Something isn't clear... they must have a collective mind of sorts. My thoughts have been confirmed by the recent attacks on the barge by those horrors.
I guess anything can happen in the Zone, but if your estimates are correct, we're in some deep trouble.
Why do you not trust people?
Because I've been through too much.
I think I'll go.
And what is our final task?

You'll see. As you know, the most insidious enemy of man - strangely enough - remains a man. For a long time, we've kept the vehicle station clear of all the bandits, but they keep coming back. They've been a steady threat, usually numbering from around five to seven. Let's go take care of them.
Hah, the two of us against these... We're heroes!
What you just called heroism here is commonplace for more experienced stalkers. Anyway, let's head back to the village.
It's nice that we've got a mentor like you.

Thank you, although I'm not the first - that honor goes to Wolf. I need to catch my breath, that tired me out... Oh, and I've got some info on a route from Agroprom to Yantar in case you haven't already heard of it. Rest up for a bit, and then... Agh, who am I to tell you what to do? You've certainly proven to be your own stalker, and you should be proud of it. Be free.
I'm ready, what now?

Tell me, what self-respecting stalker has never found another's secrets? The Zone is common to everybody here. Those who manage, eat. Sometimes, finding a stash is not just an achievement, but a necessity. I've hidden a backpack somewhere in the village - try to find it.
Found it... Thanks for the artifact.
Huh... I see that with your level of perception, the Zone won't be taking you so easily. Your final lesson is about to start. Take some time to prepare.
Oh, a new face? Would you like to go through some basic training?
Sure.
No, thanks.
Excellent. The biggest threat around here are the mutants. There's a herd of boars by the ravine - you and I are going to clear the place out. Try and keep them off me.
Phew, that was crazy. What now?
Well done. See if your knife's strong enough to get a few parts off of them. When you're done, let's head to the nearest anomalous zone.
What's next?

So, this pit is full of gravitational anomalies. See the artifact over there? It's called a Jellyfish, and Jellyfishes, along with every other artifact, have both positive and negative qualities... We're quite fortunate to have found one. Here, a simple detector you can use to find artifacts. Here's a bottle of Nemiroff - take a swig, in case you manage to catch any radiation. Now, take a few bolts and throw them in front of you to check if the path's safe. Let's go. I'll cover you from here on.
Hey, I got the artifact!
Well, well... I can see you'll be an experienced stalker one day. Let's head back to the village - we'll continue your training there.
That sure was something...
Tired? Heh, don't put anything away yet. The training has just begun.
Hey, stalker. Need something?
Do you have any special jobs?

Of course. Have you seen how many zombies have gathered in the Garbage? Quite strange, it hasn't been like that before... Anyway, I'll give you the coordinates to the largest cluster of these creatures, and you'll clean up everything there. What do you say?
Alright, go ahead and send me the coordinates.
I'll pass.
Here you are. Be careful out there, stalker.
The zombies have been taken care of... God damn, there were so many.

Nicely done. They probably migrated from Yantar. By the way, did you know that there's a direct path to the Wild Territory from here? If not, give me your PDA - I'll show you how to get there. Also, here's your reward.
Who are you?

Well, I'm basically a local barman, or a manager of provisions... whichever you prefer. You could say that I'm one of the few who participated in cleaning up the accident at the nuclear power plant. I'm not exactly from here, but I decided to go to the Zone on contract. I've got some experience on me, hah.
How was it there?

I was just an army draftee back then, only ever got to measure radioactivity and clean it up. However, the guys near the power station ended up waist-deep in shit. Even our technology died from the radiation, let alone the people... imagine that. So, they cleaned the roofs of graphite with freakin' shovels. Radiation is a strange thing - it curses some and spares others, like Dyatlov, who survived to end up in prison.
Tell me about yourself.

I serve as a medic. I went out on a contract here and was almost immediately assigned to the Fairway group, after some preparation. We were somehow stuck in Pripyat after the collapse of the operation - well, those of us who were still alive... then a man from the USS helped us, and then they evacuated us. I still can't get this one case out of my head: our commander sent me and a couple of guys to the kindergarten, in which - according to preliminary data - there was a device that interfered with radio communications. I don't know what came over me, I wasn't feeling myself – I couldn't see, I didn't know where my comrades were, and something pulled a veil straight over my eyes. Right in that kindergarten, I found a damn refrigerator and hid there. Then, I heard an explosion right above me and I immediately felt better for whatever reason, but the refrigerator locked up and I couldn't get out without outside help. I don't recall if I locked myself in it or if it was a poltergeist that held the door closed...
And then what happened? Why didn't you quit?

Well... I need the money, why would I have come back here otherwise? And doctors are always useful... However, there aren't a lot of them in the army at this point. Fortunately, though, I wasn't demoted for the failure of the operation, but I wasn't praised, either - unlike the major, who, by the way, is also hanging around somewhere here in the Zone.
Understood. I wish you well on your travels.
Huh? Oh, it's you...
I need medical assistance.
Alright, let me see...
Don't be ridiculous. You're okay.
How bad is it?
There we go. You're all set.
Here. I found a flight recorder.
A military one? Great. That's actually a nice gizmo you've got there - I'll take it off your hands for some paper.
I found a flight recorder.
Oh, serious? Bring it here. Let's see what these bozos are planning.
I found a flight recorder.
Ah, an excellent find! Perhaps we'll finally find the cause of these air raids in the marshes.
Brother, I have found a flight recorder device under the wreckage of a helicopter.
I am pleased. With this, the infidels will burn.
Are you interested in data from a flight recorder?
Wha-of course! Give it here.
I've found a flight recorder from a helicopter wreckage.
Good find! Well done, soldier.
Hey, do you have information on stashes?
Sure do. I'll part with one for six thousand.
Pleasure doin' business. There ya go.
Heard you got information on stashes.
You heard right. We always keep an eye on loot after raids. It's yours for six and a half thousand.
Sweet. Enjoy.
You got any info on stashes?
I've got everything and more - if you've got the cash, that is. Got plenty of spare info from various sources. Eight thousand for this one, no less.
Right. Here are your coordinates.
Looking for information on stashes. Got it?
Damn, how'd you know? I got info before others could even find out. Whatever, seven grand and it's all yours.
Knock yourself out.
Any stash information for sale?

Heh, yeah... Sometimes, when stalkers around here grab a bottle, they drunkenly slip info on their stashes. Don't know what they keep in there, but what I do know is the value. Seven thousand and it's all yours.
Much appreciated.
You're the local supplier, right? What services do you offer?

That's correct. I can provide ammunition, which our guys find in raids from time to time, in exchange for any foreign munitions you bring us. We also have some foreign ones, and the exchange ratio for everything expect RPG warheads is one to one. The weapons we have are all fine and dandy, but a few prefer using more domestic firearms, ammunition for which is more abundant - having anything to shoot with helps keep us alive and well. I can also give you RPG projectiles and M209 underbarrel grenades, which we've received in abundance for carrying out tasks, though unfortunately, we don't have any more grenade launchers to go with it. Medical assistance is also something I can provide.
What kinds of munitions do you exchange?

I have two hundred 9x19 rounds that I can exchange for an equal number of 9x18 armor piercing rounds, about three hundred 5.56x45 rounds in exchange for 5.45x39 rounds, twenty F1 grenades for the same amount of M209 grenades and ten RGD-5 grenades in exchange for three RPG warheads.
Think I'll make an exchange.
Great. What do you have?
I'll take two hundred 9x19 rounds in exchange for two hundred 9x18 armor piercing rounds.
I'll take three hundred 5.56x45 rounds in exchange for three hundred 5.45x39 rounds.
I'll take twenty F1 grenades in exchange for twenty M209 grenades.
I'll take ten RGD-5 grenades in exchange for three RPG warheads.
I've changed my mind.
I saw your message. How come you've turned into such a do-gooder?

...Don't push your luck. The only reason you even stand in this place is because things have been going to crap. We've lost several important people to the military, who used to roam around here... and we haven't been able to find information necessary to us. If we return to Dushman, he's gonna tear our balls off and shove them right down our throats, which is why we're stationed here for the time being. At this point, I see no use in fighting random stalkers.
What kind of help do you need?

Any. We have no supplies here, no standard equipment - only what we manage to find after successful operations. You can also talk to our supplier; for a fee, he'll share some excess equipment equipment with you.
Got any special jobs?

We actually came here to retrieve info from Lab X8, which is located near the Yubileiny service center north of here; inside, there was an elevator that allowed us to go down to "minus first floor", but we got interrupted by the fucking military. It's because of them that we've ended up this deep in shit. Dushman's going to kill us anyway, but maybe there are a few documents left... we'd have something useful to leave with, at least. I'd head over there again with the guys, but there aren't many of us left and it'd be too much to handle, since we'd rather not spend any more manpower than we need to trying to somehow get away from the center of the fucking Zone. Maybe you could head down to X8 - there could be something left, and, well... you'll earn some good money at the same time. You feel like going?
I'll go.
No, thanks.
Here's what I managed to find.
Stack of papers doesn't seem very thick... Nevertheless, there are some interesting points here. It won't be hard to find a buyer for such a find. Here's your cut.
Is there anywhere I may travel, brother?

Certainly. I may ask our brothers to lead you - in exchange for a donation to the brotherhood. You may be taken to the outskirts of Pripyat east of here, to Jupiter to the west, and to the Red Forest located to the southwest.
To which places may I travel to, brother?
There are ways to the Outskirts east of here, to Jupiter to the west, and to the Red Forest located to the southwest.
I'd like to travel somewhere.
To which location do you seek to go, brother?
To the Outskirts. %c[255,238,153,26][1000 RU]
To the Red Forest. %c[255,238,153,26][5000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
To which places may I travel to, brother?
I can not escort you personally, but our brothers may show you where to go - for a fee. We've got positions set up in the Red Forest, Jupiter and Pripyat. We would be glad to assist you at any time.
Where can the guides take me?
To the Red Forest for five thousand rubles, Jupiter for two thousand and Pripyat for one thousand.
I'd like to travel somewhere.
Certainly. Where would you like the guides to take you?
To the Red Forest. %c[255,238,153,26][5000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
To which places may I travel to, brother?
I personally can not escort you, but our brothers may show you where to go - for a fee. We've got positions set up in the Red Forest, Jupiter and Pripyat. We would be glad to assist you at any time.
Where can the guides take me?
To the Red Forest for five thousand rubles, Jupiter for two thousand and Pripyat for one thousand.
I'd like to travel somewhere.
Certainly. Where would you like the guides to take you?
To the Red Forest. %c[255,238,153,26][5000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
To which places may I travel to, brother?

There are several - we have routes that lead to the Red Forest, Outskirts and Pripyat. I cannot take you to any of these locations myself, but you may go with your brothers - for a fee. I don't believe you'll find it a problem, however.
Where can the guides take me?
To the Red Forest for six thousand rubles, Outskirts for two thousand and Pripyat for one thousand.
I'd like to travel somewhere, brother.
Of course. Where would you like to go?
To the Red Forest. %c[255,238,153,26][6000 RU]
To the Outskirts. %c[255,238,153,26][2000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Remind me, what do you have?

This is what I've got: four mags of 9x18 for five bottles, two 5.45x39 mags for five bottles, four 5.45x39 mags for ten bottles, three packs of 12x70 for ten bottles, one mag of 7.62x54 7N1 for ten bottles, three box mags for the PKP for fifteen bottles and seven thousand rubles, and a Berill suit for twenty bottles.
Who are you?

A new client... Understand that I'm not interested in who you are or where you come from - you choose what you need from the list and wait exactly one day until I get the goods. Moreover, I do not accept refusals - I don't have time for games, or bullshit, and I work without prepayments. Everything will be exactly on time, and you can order no more than one item.
How do you cooperate with the Monolith and how do you manage to get such unique armor and weapons?

If I'm not interested in who you are, then the feeling should be mutual, right? I'll tell you this only your reassurance: I'm an intermediary. You're lucky that I decided to cooperate with you, as I can be very selective with my clients. Believe me.
I want to place an order.
Choose what interests you.
Pistols.
Remember, you may choose one and only one. Here.
The Steppe Eagle - a hand-made pistol based on the Desert Eagle design. Finely tuned to achieve incredible accuracy. It'll cost you eight thousand.
You'll receive a message on your PDA from me in exactly twenty-four hours.
Alpine - a modified SIG P220 with an extended magazine. It'll cost you sixty-five thousand.
March - modified UDP Compact, high caliber and quick-firing. It'll cost you seven thousand..
Shotguns and SMGs.
Right. Choose one of the following.
The Frasier - a handmade sub-machine gun based on the MP5. Increased caliber, improved characteristics over standard counterpart. It'll cost you ninety-five hundred.
The Carabiner - an army-modified SPAS-12 with reduced recoil and automatic firing mode. It'll cost you eleven thousand.
The Armsel Protecta - a shotgun based on the design of the Striker shotgun. It'll cost you seventeen thousand.
I didn't find what I was looking for.
Sniper and assault rifles.
Here's what I've got - pick one.

Storm - a modified OTs-14 Groza manufactured for Spetsnaz special forces, secretly leaked to the masses. One of the advantages worth noting is the increased magazine capacity. It'll cost you nineteen thousand.
The H&K G36 - a rare sight in the zone. It'll cost you fourteen thousand.
The FN F2000. A Belgian rarity and a decent assault rifle. It'll cost you seventeen thousand.
The Tide - an exclusive modification of the VSS Vintorez. Lower rate of fire, but increased stopping power. It'll cost you twenty thousand.
The SVU2-A - an evolution of the SVUmk-2 sniper rifle. This weapon used to belong to Max, the legendary guardian of Freedom. It'll cost you twenty-four thousand.
The SVD Lynx - an army modification that combines increased accuracy and stopping power. It'll cost you eighteen thousand.
Gauss rifle. A trophy weapon - you can count the number of these in the Zone on your fingers. Absolute accuracy and damage with almost no recoil included. The price is one-hundred and fifty thousand.
Suits.
Alright, choose one.

A Monolith exoskeleton - the best combination of protective characteristics. In addition, you won't get this anywhere else, unless you are a certain representative of the brotherhood. The price is at a hundred thousand.
A mercenary exoskeleton - perhaps one of the most reliable means of protection. It'll cost you seventy-five thousand.
Bandit exoskeleton. Exclusivity in its purest form. It'll cost you sixty-five thousand.
A Monolith suit featuring a closed-cycle breathing system; as with the exoskeleton, you are unlikely to see it anywhere else. It'll cost you seventy thousand.
A Mercenary suit with a closed breathing system. Excellent protection from anomalies and a real rarity for the average stalker. It'll cost you fifty thousand.
I've changed my mind.
I want to order.
Hope you have the funds to afford these.
Yeah, give me the Steppe Eagle.
Come again.
I'll take the SIG-220 Alpine.
Give me the USP March.
I'd like the MP-5 Frasier.
Gimme the Carabiner.
Let me get the Protecta.
I'll place an order for the OT-14 Storm.
Wouldn't mind the HK G36.
FN-2000 sounds like a nice pick.
Definitely want the VSS Tide.
SVU2-A, eh? Sure.
I'll grab that SVD Lynx.
I'll order the Monolith exoskeleton.
Gimme the mercenary exoskeleton.
I'll toss some cash at the bandit exoskeleton.
I'll place an order for the Monolith SEVA suit.
Give me the mercenary SEVA suit.
Gauss rifle. Right now.
Forget it.
Salutations, fellow brother. My duty is to provide technical support for our brethren in the area.
Greetings, brother. I carry out Its will by preserving the equipment of our brotherhood.
'Sup, homie? Armor and weapon repairs - all by me.
They say you have interesting goods in exchange for Duty patches.

Of course! I can offer two hundred and ten 5.56 rounds for twenty patches, fifty 7.62 rounds for fifteen patches, twenty M209 underbarrel grenades for fifty patches, a scientific Freedom suit for fifty patches, a Freedom exoskeleton for sixty-five patches and a unique SVD for a hundred patches.
I've got the patches.

Awesome, dude! Take your pick - two hundred and ten 5.56 rounds for twenty patches, fifty 7.62 rounds for fifteen patches, twenty M209 underbarrel grenades for fifty patches, a scientific Freedom suit for fifty patches, a Freedom exoskeleton for sixty-five patches and a unique SVD for a hundred patches!
Two hundred and ten rounds of 5.56.
Fifty 7.62x54 rounds.
Twenty M209 grenades should be good.
Gimme that scientific suit.
I'll take the exo.
Let me have that unique-looking SVD.
I won't take anything. I've changed my mind.
I've brought some vodka.
That's great! Is there anything particular you want?
Six 9x18 mags.
Three 5.45 mags.
Six 5.45 mags.
Some buckshot ammo.
Two mags of 7.62 7N1.
Three boxes for the PKP.
The Berill.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
Who are you?

The local cook, I guess. I can't even make something simple like an omelette, but somehow that's the assigned role I received in the army. I'm not a real soldier, so they put me here in Yantar. Anyway, they call me Spirit. Usually I take to drinking - it's so depressing around here. And you know... this is the main base of the Ecologists. My officers come here for inspections from time to time, and they don't like me drinking. Last time they were here, they poured my vodka out right before my eyes, bastards.
Go on.

Well, I know that getting ammo around here is rough, especially when Sakharov doesn't even sell any. I can hook you up with some stuff, but only Soviet-era shit, unfortunately. I've also got a few outfits - everything I've managed to steal is mine. What do you say? I can offer you four 9x18 mags or two mags of 5.45 for five bottles, and four mags for ten bottles. For ten bottles, I can share one mag of 7.62mm 7N1. And for twenty bottles, I'll fetch you an entire Berill suit from the bins. Don't think I'm a scoundrel... it's not that bad, the lion's share goes to the guys. They've left me their equipment in a stash. I'll leave any goods between the hangars outside the bunker. I buy retail.
I'll consider it. Thank you.
What kind of place is this?
This, my man, is the flea market. Us here sell bit by bit. Truthfully, the stuff here is pretty garbage, but we have to make do. So, you trading?
Are you the only trader here?

Me? Of course not! There are other people here making deals and stuff. We do have one rule, though: nothing major's traded before sunset. When the sun's up, I'm around here - my goods are low cost, and I only have a humble amount of wares to offer. At night, though, the real life begins - the goods are completely different and top tier.
Who are you?
I'm with the military, callsign "Peregrine". We've got troops stationed here to help out with maintaining the equipment. I'm also a part-time technician - if something breaks, I can repair it.
What's the current situation?

To be honest with you, it's shit. I don't have the tools I need, all thanks to the outstanding supply of the higher-ups. The equipment the Ecologists have got here isn't really making it easy for us, and it's gonna need some higher quality modifications... Managed to get the old receiver here repaired, though it's still spouting a bunch of gibberish. Our guys kicked the bucket at the Army Warehouses a couple of years ago, and it's still transmitting their voices.
Well, this is the Zone, you never know what'll happen. Anyway, best wishes.
Who are you?

I'm a paramedic... used to be, at least. They call me Aspirin. Yeah, really. I can patch up any minor wounds, but as for serious injuries... Either a helicopter or the Zone itself will have to save you. And we rarely call in 'copters.
Do you sell, you know... "medicine"?
Hey, keep it down, the general's nearby. Yeah, we've got schmucks who sell that stuff, but I'm not one of them. I'll patch you up with the legitimate stuff, though.
Thanks.
I need medical assistance.
Yeah, I'll fix you up - for a fee.
You're fit as a fiddle. Now go, I'm busy.
How bad is it?
You're fine. The door's that way. Also, don't forget to take your "medicine".
What is it?
Professor, you must have something that interests you more than anything else.

Yes, I do have something. I require fresh brain tissue from a controller in order to conduct extensive research into the psy-emission phenomenon. In exchange, I will offer you ten scientist medkits, ten military medkits, a Veles detector and three packs of anabiotics. Provided you return, of course.
I'm back, and with the brain issue as well. Here, Professor.
Splendid! Now, I can offer you four scientific first-aid kits, five army kits, a Veles-class detector or two packs of anabiotics. The choice is yours.
I'll take four scientific medkits.
Five army medkits.
Could use the Veles.
Anabiotics would be preferred.
I've changed my mind.
Tell me about yourself.

What's there to tell? I'm the local bartender and doctor - but who can tell amidst this crap, yeah? We've been stuck here for days, barely maintaining ourselves. I took part in the defense of the president's palace back then, migrated to Switzerland. Then I came to the Zone. I enjoyed visiting the Bar with friends, drinking and reminiscing of older days... During one of such visits I was offered a place in the the Syndicate. It was barely upholding at the time, so Dushman and I are sort of pioneers in this. So what? The roundabouts are fitting, there are people who've been in Afghanistan and Georgia. But people from the Baltic aren't too eager to come, never mind the first world countries.
Heard that you're interested in faction patches.

How can I put this? Personally, no, I'm not "interested" in them - however, with morale being rather low lately, it's an optimal method for our guys to earn some spoils of war. Plus, the high-ups want them. Here's how it works: you bring me patches from stalkers, you get some gear or nothing at all. All of it for ten patches of any faction, apart from those of Ecologists and the Monolith, you have a chance to get a subpar artifact, or not get jack shit. With fifty patches, you'll have a chance to get a decent artifact and some rather solid gear, but there's also a chance that you won't get anything. And for ten Monolith or Ecologist patches, you will get a pretty good artifact with the same chance as for fifty patches of any other faction. Fifty Monolith or Ecologist patches will guarantee you an outstanding item and good equipment dedicated only to the most experienced of stalkers, no chance of losing. You might ask, "why so generous?"... Because many people prefer to keep the patches for themselves as combat trophies.
What about you? What are you doing with them all?
I collect them. Not your business - since I organized this "lottery", why should it be?
I have some patches.
Excellent, which ones?
Clear Sky, ten patches.
Freedom, ten patches.
Loners, ten patches.
Ecologists', ten patches.
Bandits, ten patches.
Duty, ten patches.
Monolith, ten patches.
Military, ten patches.
Clear Sky, fifty patches.
Freedom, fifty patches.
Loners, fifty patches.
Ecologists'. Even got fifty.
Bandits, fifty patches.
Duty, fifty patches.
Monolith, fifty patches.
Military, fifty patches.
Changed my mind.
Here, take your artifact.
Here.
Here, take it.
Here's your artifact.
Someone got lucky tonight.
You get a nice present.
Here's a solid artifact.
You're a lucky man! Here's something for the radiation.
A beautiful artifact. Here you go.
Two artifacts! You're lucky.
And here's the jackpot!
You're lucky.
An excellent kit for an artifact hunter!
A rare and wonderful artifact.
Damn, you're lucky!
Jackpot!
Alas, you didn't get anything.
You're quite unlucky.
Better luck next time.
Excellent equipment for an excellent marksman.
Ideal for long-range attacks.
Hey, what's up?
Nothing much. I'm Leshiy, nice to meet you. I'm the local guide and scout.
And how's the local intelligence? I presume you've visited many places.

Indeed. I've even been in an anomaly. That was when I was still a mercenary... entered a spatial bubble with my squad. It's a long story. Anyway, I offer guides to the Cordon, Yantar and Yanov station in Jupiter. Forty-five hundred, five thousand, and six thousand rubles respectively.
I'll keep that in mind.
Lead me somewhere.
Sure, man. Where to?
Need the money first, pal.
Here, all yours.
Got the money?
Here, keep it.
Did you bring the money?
Of course. Here.
Forgot it.
I've changed my mind.
I need a heli. Is this possible to organize?
It is, but we won't be using up fuel just for you. You'll have to prove that you're worth the lift.
To which places do you offer transport?
To our base in Agroprom for five thousand rubles, as well as the gas station in the Darkscape for three thousand and the mobile lab at lake Yantar for ten thousand.
I could use a lift.
Where to?
To the military base in Agroprom. %c[255,238,153,26][5000 RU]
To the gas station in the Darkscape. %c[255,238,153,26][3000 RU]
To the mobile lab in Yantar. %c[255,238,153,26][10000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Can you organize a trip? There's somewhere I need to fly.
Yeah, I can take you to the Cordon and Yantar... Wait, who are you, even? I offer transport, but not for an ordinary soldier like you. Shoo.
Where do you fly to, again?
To our checkpoint in the Cordon for five thousand rubles, as well as the base in Yantar for seven thousand.
I require a pilot.
Alright, our next flight leaves shortly. Where to?
To the checkpoint in the Cordon. %c[255,238,153,26][5000 RU]
To the base in Yantar. %c[255,238,153,26][7000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Hey, why are you standing there?

If I want to stand, then that's my own business... Just kidding. I have to be in constant sight, since I'm a local guide. And please, don't stare at my equipment - it'll be easier for me that way. I can take you to a few places if you want, namely the observation outpost here in the swamp, as well as the pump station, the old church and the machine yard. I also offer trips to the rookie village in the Cordon, as well as to Agroprom and the Bar. All of it will cost you.
Can you repeat your routes?

These are the routes I take: the observation outpost for three hundred rubles, the pump station and the old church both for five hundred, the machine yard for eight hundred, the rookie village in the Cordon for fifteen hundred, Agroprom for two thousand and the Bar for four thousand.
I'd like to use your services.
Alright, where to?
The observation outpost. %c[255,238,153,26][300 RU]
The pump station. %c[255,238,153,26][500 RU]
The machine yard. %c[255,238,153,26][800 RU]
The Rookie Village in the Cordon. %c[255,238,153,26][1500 RU]
I've changed my mind.
What do you do around here?
You blind or something? I'm the local guide here. I can take you to our outpost in the Truck Cemetery, as well as our warehouse in Jupiter. It'll cost you.
Let's go.
Where we goin'?
To the Truck Cemetery. %c[255,238,153,26][1500 RU]
To the container warehouse in Jupiter. %c[255,238,153,26][8000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
You're a guide, right?

Yeah, they call me Tourist. I like to wander around in poorly-mapped areas to find secret paths that no other stalkers know about. Anyway, here's where I can take you: to the Nuclear Power Plant for twelve thousand rubles, Pripyat for three thousand, Yanov station in Jupiter for four thousand, the Radar for eight thousand, the Jupiter Underground for just one thousand and Zaton, via Garry, for four thousand.
Where do you travel to again?

To the Nuclear Power Plant for twelve thousand rubles, Pripyat for three thousand, Yanov station in Jupiter for four thousand, the Radar for eight thousand, the Jupiter Underground for just one thousand and Zaton, via Garry, for four thousand.
Guide me.
Where?
To the Chernobyl NPP. %c[255,238,153,26][12000 RU]
To the Jupiter Underground. %c[255,238,153,26][1000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Who are you?
Nice to meet you, bro. Name's Garry, and I'm a guide - usually roam around the center of the Zone. I can take you to the Bar, Pripyat, the Red Forest, Zaton and the Jupiter Underground.
Forgot. Where can you lead me?

I can offer trips to the Bar for six thousand rubles, Pripyat for three thousand, the Red Forest for twenty-five hundred, the Skadovsk in Zaton for two thousand and the Jupiter Underground for fifteen hundred.
Take me somewhere.
Okay, where?
To the Red Forest. %c[255,238,153,26][2500 RU]
To Jupiter Underground. %c[255,238,153,26][1500 RU]
I've changed my mind.
You look like an interesting character.

Pathfinder Pilot at your service. There aren't many places I can take you, but it'll definitely be much faster and safer. I offer services to Pripyat as well as its outskirts via fellow guide Garry, though I can take you to Jupiter myself.
Give me your travel list again.
I can talk to Garry about leading you to Pripyat for four thousand, as well as the outskirts for five thousand. I can lead you to Yanov station in Jupiter by myself, for two thousand.
Take me places.
Where to?
To the Outskirts. %c[255,238,153,26][5000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Are you a guide?

Yep, Navigator's the name. Can take you to a few places for a modest fee. Rookies are my customers most of the time, but I can lead any experienced stalker as well - no shame in it. I'll break it down: you pay, I get you wherever you want to go and I return here. I can take you to Yantar, the Great Swamp, the Army Warehouses, the Garbage, the Cordon and Jupiter.
Sorry, where can you escort me?

To the the Garbage for seven hundred, the Army Warehouses for one thousand, the Rookie Village in the Cordon for three thousand, Yantar for thirty-five hundred, Yanov station in Jupiter for six thousand and the Great Swamp, also for six thousand.
Need to be lead somewhere.
Yeah, where?
To the Army Warehouses. %c[255,238,153,26][1000 RU]
To the Great Swamp. %c[255,238,153,26][6000 RU]
I've changed my mind.
Are you another bandit? Why haven't you opened fire yet?

Heh, no. I'm not a bandit, and I won't shoot unless you give me a good reason to. I'm a hunter, but I wouldn't put it past anyone in the Zone to mistake me for a bandit. Those pigs were just here out of coincidence, then you showed to clean up. As you can see, I manage a small, cozy, and generally safe bar... well, for the most part. By the way, name's Butcher.
So you're an artifact hunter?

Eh, not quite. We don't collect artifacts, we don't adhere to any common views on the Zone and we certainly don't try to unravel its secrets. All we do is hunt mutants, and not because they represent - in our opinion - a threat, as Duty seems to wholeheartedly believe, but because of the thrill of the hunt. Many of us were former hunters, both amateurs and professionals outside of the Zone, though many perished, since they weren't expecting the level of... unpredictability the Zone showed them.
I see. Well, you work at a bar. Do you have anything for sale?

I do, though my stock is nothing special. Some stalkers bring mutant parts to me and I sell them. Also have a few other goods, like provisions, medicine and equipment. And if you're up for hunting mutants for coin, I've got a few jobs.
I'll keep that in mind.
Why don't the traders and guards at the flea market live in the hangar? It seems a lot safer, and more habitable.

The stalkers at the flea market have been around for a few years at this point, while we've only gotten here recently... though, they were dispersed by Duty because they usually sell things considered "dangerous". What a fucking joke. Apparently, they somehow made an agreement with them. They really don't have anything to do here and they don't understand us, and frankly we don't understand them and their ideals. We hunt to survive, while they sit at their flea market like owls, collecting goodies and artifacts. Generally, those guys are pretty strange... but they're alright.
Since you're an expert hunter, I'd like to know some more about mutants.

There are a few cute rodents in the Zone, called "tushkanos". You've seen them for sure. They don't really appear dangerous, but in packs, they can easily kill even an experienced stalker. There was a case where a special squad of Dutyers went to sweep a bloodsucker lair. Those idiots made camp somewhere in the middle of the Agroprom complex... One of the guys took off somewhere while another screwed around on his PDA. No one was keeping the night watch. Morning came, and no one was there - something was wrong. The first people to enter that room were in for a big surprise... The throats of the squad members had been all chewed up. Typical tushkano traces. God knows why the rodents just up and left their meal. Anyway, the rest of the soldiers decided to head to the lair and finish the job, writing off the deaths of their comrades afterwards. That's how those men perished. Some stalker ended up retrieving their PDAs, having a new story to tell in the Bar for shits and giggles.

Every rookie encounters a few dogs at the Cordon, as well as in the Great Land. They don't really differ that much from their "prototypes", so to speak - except they're blind, but that doesn't really keep them down, since their other senses have evolved... especially their ability to smell. They can take out newbies like fish in a barrel, and sometimes more experienced stalkers, too, mostly thanks to their maneuverability and sudden strikes. Hey, here's a story for you... Somebody made it a habit to snatch some sausage from the Bar. Everyone raised some fuss, tore up the security, and some men from Duty even ended up keeping watch and check who was stealing. Eventually, they saw a dog run in through a hole in the fence and, naturally, shot it down. In the morning, a solemn-looking stalker comes into the Bar and asks about the dog... Barman realizes what's happening and tells him to ask the guys from Duty. Turns out the fresh-faced lad was moving to the Zone with that dead dog, who was his pet. They went though a lot... The guy was also an orphan, and then this happens to him. Ever since that moment, any wise guy who crosses the border into the Zone with a pet either keeps moving or makes dinner out of his "little friend" for other stalkers... just to keep tensions low. By the way, all that sausage was actually stolen by a local alcoholic.

There are dogs, and there are pseudodogs. Why "pseudo", you ask? Well, they originally evolved from wild wolves. On their own, they are easily dispatched by point blank buckshot rounds, much like ordinary wild dogs. However, a pack of pseudodogs is nothing to scoff at. Moreover, they conjure clones of themselves that swarm you... and when that happens, you need to find and kill the real one for the phantoms to stop appearing, otherwise you end up wasting precious ammo and risk getting yourself badly hurt.

Let me tell you about snorks. The most common theory is that they are former military personnel who guarded the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant before the second explosion, when it completely fried their brains and turned them into abominations. Something like a zombie, only... even more bestial and primitive. They crawl on all fours, claw, kick, and even pounce fairly long distances to close in on their prey. Just one is dangerous, but a group of them? Might as well off yourself right then and there. If you ever come across snorks, sidestep their pounce, then blast their ass full of lead. Heck, if you're confident, but also have a death wish, you can kill them in midair. Good luck with that.

Zombies. You know those cheap American movies where zombies just grunt, moan, and attack with their hands? Well, it ain't like that in Zone... sort of. Most zombies here are former stalkers, their brains completely mashed, torn, and battered by the Brain Scorcher. A lot of them still retain their speech, and are also capable of operating firearms. Nobody understands what they say... although, a friend of mine recently came to visit after a long expedition in Jupiter, and he was attacked by zombies. The paleness of his face said it all... Said they were begging for help, that they were tired, hungry. Who knows. Poor bastard. Sakharov can give you a better understanding. There's also a more barbaric, generic type of zombie, like the ones you see in movies. They're slow, and not at all capable of using guns, so it should be simple to kill them... Just don't let them corner you. They are also masters of feigning. Shoot them anywhere other than the head, they'll fall over and wait for your closure. You get your knife out, then stab the fuckers right in the skull. If you're skilled enough, you can even have at them them while they're moving.

Bloodsuckers? Let's see. Rumor has it they're mutated human beings. Whether or not they mutated from the radiation after the explosions or were scientifically modified by other humans, I don't know. What I do know, however, is that they're one of the most dangerous predators inhabiting the Zone. Not only do they boast incredible speed, but they also camouflage themselves, making them extremely dangerous and aggressive beasts. They use stealth and circle around you, tiring your legs out, waiting for the perfect moment to strike - and when they do, you lose consciousness. See, their name speaks for itself. They drain so much blood that by the time you unhinge those slimy feelers off your neck, you might as well be a piece of paper floating in the wind. I've heard stories of a stalker having committed suicide while being circled indefinitely by a bloodsucker. It's almost like a game to them, really. When they're not sucking your blood through a straw, their razor sharp claws come into play. Just like snorks, you can avoid their attacks, but you gotta expect it - be alert, use a shotgun, aim for the head, then fire. Rookies end up with empty mags and unique wounds. You'd better find a high spot or stick close to an object, so that you don't creak up behind and look at both of them, because suddenly this bastard will appear before you, but squeeze and shoot the weapon more tightly. That's the best tactic if they find you alone. Running away from them is problematic.

Burers. They are near-legendary creatures, the existence of which many don't even want to know... Personally, I shit myself with fear just thinking about them. The best advice I can give regarding burers is not to go in dungeons and any kinds of empty complexes, laboratories in particular, because they love dwelling in such places. Recently, though, they have been sighted in pretty much every place in the Zone, and this is primarily thanks to to the actions of the Marked One, who turned off the Brain Scorcher. Chimeras too, for example, used to live closer to the center of the Zone, but then suddenly migrated and increased their population. Apparently, someone who runs all of this in the center of the Zone has got some influence over these creatures, and uses them as a kind of Cerberus on the last approaches towards their "stronghold". If you get into trouble and end up unable to escape, I'd advise you to protect your head, because they've got relatively powerful telekinesis powers. They can also send a focused impulse and knock you off your feet, as well as take away your weapons and exhaust you, somehow influencing the gravity around you. They resemble fat, hideous dwarfs, who wear huge shoes with their own characteristic sounds, as well as black cloaks, strangely enough sewn almost their size. I too think that they are the result of experiments in secret laboratories. There are also different subspecies of burers - for example, fire and electric, just like poltergeists. Some argue that the poltergeist is an evolutionary stage of the burer... however, if an electric poltergeist acts on you only with telekinesis, then a corresponding burer can easily throw a ball of lightning at you or even a whole Electra anomaly, the size of a substation.

Controllers are no joke: those monsters emit a steady psy-background, and they can manipulate the consciousness of any person. It's absolutely fatal to approach them without the right type of protection, and you're generally better off staying away from any places they might be dwelling in. They'll most likely just burn your brain out - not even zombifying you - in order to make some juicy grub out of you right then and there. Legend's going around saying that they can even talk, but I don't really believe it... Their high level of intellect is beyond doubt, though. Sometimes they can stage clever ambushes. They often wander alone, greedy for food, or thinking about whatever goes on in that screwed-up head of theirs... A stalker once dropped by and told me and the boys that there was a weird creature that settled down around Rostok. He went to have a look, but was stopped by a sudden, severe headache that almost made him drop his gun. So, he backed off, thinking it was just radiation... The rest of us went with him to scoop the place out, came in – and I also felt a headache! Later we went back prepared, having taken some special pills that basically killed any emotions we had... I looked around and saw a man-shaped figure sitting in the darkness. I opened fire, but it disappeared - and then, the bastard came out behind my back, and I shot him. Then I heard a faint, yet familiar voice... and couldn't believe it. I shot down my friend Vasyuk. Eventually we managed to get rid of that mutant freak, but I quit hunting ever since and ended up opening a bar here. I was fortunate not to get killed... Redhead was a smart guy, so he took off to the north after what happened.

And the cats... Have you seen those things? Oh, god. Only this place can turn pets into feral beasts. Their whole thyroid gland is swollen from all the radiation, along with tumors in their cheeks. I don't know why those cats have become like this. These creatures have become bigger with sharper claws, and they run like crazy. People usually have to get domestic cats down from trees... Here, you're the one who gets chased around. To make matters worse, they've developed a pack mentality, similar to dogs and wolves. These creatures are wild and they can be found anywhere, so keep an eye on your surroundings at all times. They come running, and if you aren't careful, they will cling onto your ass and bite a chunk off it.

Not many people here believe in the paranormal, and everyone has their own faith. Some people believe in their own strength, some believe in their leaders and some believe in alien intervention... but certainly not in God. However, there is still a monster by the name of "poltergeist", because how else would you describe a translucent flying shit that throws objects at you? Still, there's pretty much nothing in common between the mutant and the type of entity in folklore. You can kill it in quite ordinary ways, it doesn't react to salt - we had a poor bastard that tried it - and looks like a flying electric anomaly, or less commonly, a fire essence. The electric one, like a burer, loves showering you with all sorts of random garbage, but the fire one is able to somehow create a jet of fire right in front of your fucking face - similar in effect to a geyser, and extremely hot. Shoot directly into the essence - you won't miss, but it is very difficult to kill because of its speed and maneuverability. In a few cases, stalkers have spotted some kind of black or smoky poltergeist. Nothing certain is known about its properties, but it's quite a rare specimen, and probably because meeting with it means death in the overwhelming majority of cases. It is even more difficult to kill because the smoke is much less localized, and thus aiming and shooting at its core is harder.

There are also creatures whose tales are told in front of campfires. They are called Fractures. Humanoid creatures with hypertrophic arms and necks, they possess an abnormal hand that can break a person's chest, while the other is more often than not normal, without any anomalous property. There are a lot of stories about the fact that Fractures often like to come into contact with stalkers and ask for all kinds of crap, from cans to imported toothpaste. If you aren't lucky and you don't have what it asks of you, then prepare for battle or certain death... especially death, because Fractures often come into contact during a favorable situation for them; for example, if you are alone and he's already holding you from behind with his bucketed hand. If you have what he asks of you, then don't rush and hand it over; then move away from it quietly and on all fours, it won't harm you. Well, it's all stories, who knows. Some even leave provisions in places where Fractures have been seen, in vain hopes to drive them off.

Here's another one: the pseudogiant. Usually, its height never exceeds that of a human's... however, its powerful paws can cause very strong shock waves, which is how it earned its name. Until recently, again, nothing about it was known, and it is most likely another of those abominations from the laboratories, thanks to the underground assholes who love to rummage around every single complex and not close any doors behind them. To the north, there was some kind of military guy who never shut the door at some facility... at the Iron Forest in Zaton, I believe. Since then, these giants have been observed even in the vicinity of the Jupiter plant. By looking at some of its features, it is possible to determine that "it" was once a man... like the small, hanging arms in front of the main ones, its skin, and a few other characteristics. It's got some sharp teeth, but don't worry about that - it's more likely to just knock you down and crush you. And don't take its awkward appearance into account, because it never falls down and never goes astray. The best thing to do before going near an area where a pseudogiant has been spotted is to grab a couple of rifle grenades and a machine gun, as the skin and bones of the mutant show excellent resistance to small arms, and the creature itself is very resilient.

The chimera can rightfully be considered at the top of the food chain in the Zone. How come? It is a very clever creature - a nocturnal predator that can pounce at you with a single jump from a distance of several tens of meters. Four-legged mutant, has two heads, for which it has received its nickname. It is also very durable and has sharp claws, capable of tearing through even the skin of a pseudogiant. It lets out a characteristic roar while jumping, frighteningly similar to a person's. They've have mainly been encountered in the northern parts of the Zone, in open places near facilities or complexes. As told by local hunter Trapper, they have their own sphere of influence, where they rest and hunt during late at night. There is also a subspecies, namely the black chimera. It cannot be seen at all in the dark, which makes it much more dangerous than its relatives - the usual ones have almost human skin color. It is also said to be stronger and more enduring. Escaping from a chimera is impossible - it's better to find a narrow room that will reduce its ability to maneuver, or try to jump aside while it leaps at you.

Wild boars and flesh. The latter are an example of a terribly mutated pig, as proven by scientists - rather sluggish and weak... Only a complete moron could get under its "bladed" paws, which will penetrate virtually any armor. As for boars, differ little from their relatives outside the Zone, apart from the fact that they are larger and more dangerous... Oh, and their hooves are much stronger, and can cut through fabric and human flesh effortlessly. It's enough just to jump aside and move somewhere in a couple of meters when these beasts rush at you, to avoid their fangs. Oftentimes, the meat of both wild boars and flesh is consumed, but not without being treated beforehand, to avoid radiation poisoning.

Karliks... Thanks for helping me gather information about them - here's what I've jotted down. They mainly reside in underground complexes, most of which have previously been used for experiments on people. Apparently, Karliks are the result of such experiments. They possess supernatural strength, good speed and attack most often in groups. At the moment, only one subspecies has been discovered – smoked ones. Dirty, mutated by anomalies, they emit dangerous radiation, it is better not to go near them without a Wrenched or a Bubble in your pocket.

I've heard a lot about you guys, but I wasn't sure it was true. Tell me about your faction.

Not to toot my own horn, but we're actually one of the strongest factions in the Zone, heh. We control and guard the Barrier, and we try to prevent those Duty assholes from coming here, because the goals we have are, in fact, very different. We want to co-exist with the Zone, in the best sense of the word - we believe that it is a gift to humanity. You ask how? Look around! This whole place is like a fairy tale. Anomalies that violently violate the laws of physics and creatures with amazing "properties", none of which I believe should be wiped out. Perhaps they can somehow coexist with us, or maybe we can at least borrow something from them. Nevertheless, we don't recognize the "official" approach to the Zone. Scientists may be doing a noble job, sure, but, like... All that stuff is gonna be kept by oligarchs, so what's left for common folk, you know? We just want to share the wonders of the Zone with the public, so that people won't be afraid of what they hear from the mainstream media. Instead, they'll start respecting it. Can you imagine how we, and only we, can advance in development? And what's worse is that the heads of the government can potentially develop some kind of weapon if they understand the psy-stuff that goes on around here. Anyway, we have no rules here, but discipline is still needed for banal survival, so during operations, our fighters obey the commands of the senior and experienced stalkers in the detachment. But all this is nothing more than a necessity. Are you interested in joining? We're always in need of stalkers who share our vision.
Sounds like my type of gig. I'd like to join.
Oh, man - respect! Welcome! Here, take this armor - this is the suit we give to all the newcomers. We'll see you around, man.

Oh... shit. Yeah, man, no worries. Sorry things didn't work out. You be on your way - I'll tell command.

Find a Soul artifact
Griffin has asked me to locate and return a Soul artifact.

There's no doctor here, and we've got to survive somehow. Ordinary medical equipment just isn't enough for us, and not many of the men know how to use it properly. It's hard enough taking care of everyone around here. So, I want to ask for your help. I've heard about an artifact called the Soul, said to have an ability to heal the wounds of people. Could you find one and bring it here for us?
You actually found one? I can't believe it... Thank you, stalker! This will help the others. And don't go without your reward.
Find a Battery artifact
Fanatic has asked me to find a Battery artifact for a rookie.

So, here's the deal. A rookie of ours went to Agroprom recently, all prepared for a merry adventure with a pistol in his right hand and a detector in his left. He scavenged some anomalous area for goodies and ended up finding an artifact. On his way back to the village some army patrol stopped him and took his artifact along with the rest of his stuff - now he's just sitting there, absolutely devastated by what happened. It was his first artifact, and they call it a Battery. I would go look for it myself, but I can't leave the rookies alone - they need some protection, and they've still got a lot to learn. So, will you help him out?
Ah, you've found a Battery? Excellent. I think the stalker will be happy - I sure don't need him whining and sobbing all day... Gets annoying putting up with all of that. Anyway, thanks for the help.
Find two controller brain tissues
Professor Sakharov has asked for my help in finding two controller brain tissues for his research.

Hello again! For a while, I've been attempting to research psy-emissions, and I would like your assistance. No particular mental activity will be required from you, of course - but what about the brain of a controller... or, two, if you will?
Excellent, please show them! Rather unpleasant, isn't it? That's just my job, however. Thank you for the help! Oh, and here's your reward.

Sakharov needs an artifact known as the Compass.

I, alongside the others working in this bunker, have all heard about a legendary type of artifact and it's travel from one person to another. It's called the Compass, and it has never occurred to us to try and study it in person. Will you help assist us in finding one?
Thank you for your assistance. You may have one of our best suits - I'm sure that it will save your life, likely more than once.

I'm tired of rummaging around for BTR parts... It's time to get our guys equipped with some proper gear. I could use a different kind of tools - calibration tools. Can you provide me with those?
Amazing. Never thought I'd see such sophisticated technology again... especially around here. And you won't stop me from giving you a fine discount.

We've been sitting on our asses here in Pripyat for such a long time... Surely, you've heard our story from Griffin. I've searched high and low for tools, but I've only managed to find low tier ones that aren't suitable for extensive maintenance and customization. This is outrageous. I'm a technician, and I need proper tools to work optimally. Can you help me out?

We've been sitting on our asses here in Pripyat for such a long time... Surely, you've heard our story from Griffin. I've searched high and low for tools, but I've only managed to find low tier ones that aren't suitable for extensive maintenance and customization. This is outrageous. I'm a technician, and I need proper tools to work optimally. Can you help me out?
Thank you - won't be as stressful for the guys here anymore. I'll give you a discount.

Well, we've sorted out a few issues, but there's still a lot left to do. Need better tools for even more upgrades. Mind helping out again?

As you already understand, the wilderness here is utterly unreal. Although this is a former sawmill, nothing is left but the logs. I could use some kits to work with... If you can find basic ones, please bring them here.

As you already understand, the wilderness here is utterly unreal. Although this is a former sawmill, nothing is left but the logs. I could use some kits to work with... If you can find basic ones, please bring them here.
Thanks... Things are going to be much easier. Keep this artifact - it's called a Pellicle. Quite rare.
